title: Paul Bradford (American football)
text:
Paul L. Bradford (born April 20, 1974) is a former <a href="American%20football">American football</a> <a href="cornerback">cornerback</a>. He played <a href="college%20football">college football</a> at <a href="Portland%20State%20Vikings%20football">Portland State</a>. He was <a href="Draft%20%28sports%29">drafted</a> by the <a href="San%20Diego%20Chargers">San Diego Chargers</a> in the fifth round (146th overall) of the <a href="1997%20NFL%20Draft">1997 NFL Draft</a>.
Early years.
Bradford attended <a href="Carlmont%20High%20School">Carlmont High School</a> where he was an All-state <a href="honorable%20mention">honorable mention</a> <a href="High%20school%20football">football</a> player. He then attended <a href="College%20of%20San%20Mateo">College of San Mateo</a> and <a href="Varsity%20letter">lettered</a> twice in football. He then transferred to <a href="Portland%20State%20University">Portland State University</a> where he <a href="Major%20%28academic%29">majored</a> in <a href="physical%20education">physical education</a>. In two seasons at Portland State, he recorded 80 <a href="Tackle%20%28football%20move%29">tackles</a>, four <a href="interception">interception</a>s, and 13 pass deflections.
Professional career.
Bradford was drafted in the fifth round (146th overall) by the <a href="San%20Diego%20Chargers">San Diego Chargers</a>. As a <a href="rookie">rookie</a>, he appeared in 15 games with four starts. All four starts came at left cornerback. He recorded 23 total tackles, two interceptions (one for a touchdown), one fumble recovery (for a touchdown) and seven passes defensed. He recorded his first interception while replacing <a href="Dwayne%20Harper">Dwayne Harper</a> during Week 10 against the <a href="1997%20Seattle%20Seahawks%20season">Seattle Seahawks</a>, intercepting <a href="Warren%20Moon">Warren Moon</a>, it was also his only interception returned for a touchdown. He started in place of the injured Harper the next week, intercepting a <a href="Jeff%20George">Jeff George</a> pass intended <a href="James%20Jett">James Jett</a>. On August 15, 1998, he re-signed with the Chargers. In <a href="1998%20San%20Diego%20Chargers%20season">1998</a>, he injured his <a href="knee">knee</a> and was placed on <a href="injured%20reserve">injured reserve</a>, resulting in his missing the entire season. He was re-signed by the Chargers on April 2, 1999. He was released on September 5, 1999. On March 7, 2000, he was signed by the <a href="Minnesota%20Vikings">Minnesota Vikings</a>. He was released on July 5, 2000.
Bradford was selected in the sixth (44th overall) in the 2001 <a href="2001%20XFL%20Draft">XFL Draft</a> by the <a href="Las%20Vegas%20Outlaws%20%28XFL%29">Las Vegas Outlaws</a>.
Personal life.
Bradford is married to his wife Margarita, the couple have a daughter and son, and reside in East Palo Alto.
